stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spam Emails Sent Via Possible Open Mail Relay
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
An energy sector organization reported observing spam emails sent to valid email addresses for two employees on 21 October 2014. The emails had a Subject of PREORDER and a file attachment named 20140192.zip. The data source reported three additional attempts sent to an invalid user, a former employee, and an invalid email address for a current employee.
Initial malware triage by the reporting organization using a commercial sandbox identified the malware contained in the malicious attachments as a banking trojan Zeus/Zbot variant.
The IP address 49.212.34.94 may host a misconfigured or compromised mail server acting as an open mail relay for actors sending spam.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADERS ---- EHLO mail.taikoh-kyoto.co.jp MAIL FROM:<preorder2014sumitomo@gmail.com> RCPT TO:<[redacted]> DATA Received: from [173.208.195.149] (unknown [173.208.195.149]) by mail.taikoh-kyoto.co.jp (Postfix) with ESMTPSA id E49F99882ED; Wed, 22 Oct 2014 00:00:46 +0900 (JST) Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="===============1951627353==" MIME-Version: 1.0 Subject: PREORDER To: Recipients <preorder2014sumitomo@gmail.com> From: preorder2014sumitomo@gmail.com Date: Tue, 21 Oct 2014 08:00:05 -0700 ---- END EMAIL HEADERS ---- ---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- Dear Sir, Please find attached our order,view and send qotation urgently.
Thanks and Regards.
Mrs sui lang
Purchasing manager, Sumitomo corporation ---- END EMAIL BODY ----

A review of logs by the organization revealed an additional 180 emails in the preceding 90 days from the IP address 49.212.34.9.
Some subjects for those emails included: PREORDER END OF YEAR AWARD 2014 AWARD GOOGLE AWARD Dear Beloved INSTRUCTION TO RELEASE YOUR INHERITANCE FUND Dearest in Christ..!! Investment Partner Needed. FROM MR JAMES EDWARD YOUR PAYMENT VIA CBN-VISA DEBIT CARD1111 AWARD 2014 URGENT FROM DR.MARK JOHN ATTN: Sir /Madam very urgent OK
The IP address 49.212.34.94 may host a misconfigured or compromised mail server acting as an open mail relay for actors sending spam.
According to a search on DomainTools (http://whois.domaintools.com/49.212.34.94)

172785s (1.23:59:45) 34.212.49.in-addr.arpa IN NSEC next domain name: 35.212.49.in-addr.arpa record types: NS RRSIG NSEC 172785s (1.23:59:45) 34.212.49.in-addr.arpa IN NS ns2.dns.ne.jp 3600s (01:00:00) 34.212.49.in-addr.arpa IN NS ns1.dns.ne.jp 3600s (01:00:00)

The executable contained in the malicious attachment was identified by malware analysis as a Zeus variant banking trojan.
During installation a randomly named copy of the Zeus executable will be copied from %temp% to %appdata%. Example:
%appdata%\Wawio\mytyy.exe
The Zeus variant observed in the spam emails may perform keylogging and web-browser code injection to harvest banking credentials and other information.

The malicious process attempts to check network connectivity by attempting to send an HTTP GET request to http://www.google.com:80/webhp
If successful the malware will attempt to communicate via HTTP GET and POST requests to a command and control server (C2) hosted at URL http://professionaljewelrymerchandising.com:80/dodorima/config.bin
The C2 for the botnet is resolved via fast-flux DNS with A record TTLs of 600S. Mitigations or detections via a resolved IP are unlikely to be effective.
